threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with very long lines (2557u)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects base64 encoded Powershell directives.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET MALWARE Mints.Loader CnC Activity (GET)"; flow:established,to_server; http.method; content:"GET"; http.uri; content:"|2e|php|3f|s|3d|mints"; fast_pattern; http.user_agent; content:"WindowsPowerShell/"; reference:md5,f9b55f8eb7f2b9bc6a3fbd7e6f1db477; reference:url,github.com/cert-orangecyberdefense/mintsloader; reference:url,community.emergingthreats.net/t/signature-mints-loader/2075; classtype:trojan-activity; sid:2057063; rev:1; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, affected_product Windows_11, attack_target Client_Endpoint, tls_state plaintext, created_at 2024_10_25, deployment Perimeter, confidence High, signature_severity Critical, tag c2, updated_at 2024_10_25, mitre_tactic_id TA0011, mitre_tactic_name Command_And_Control, mitre_technique_id T1071, mitre_technique_name Application_Layer_Protocol;)

alert icmp $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP Unusual PING detected"; icode:0; itype:8; fragbits:!M; content:!"ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWABCDEFGHI",depth 32; content:!"0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuv",depth 32; content:!"EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE",depth 36; content:!"WANG2"; content:!"cacti-monitoring-system",depth 65; content:!"SolarWinds",depth 72; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop,ruleset community; reference:url,krebsonsecurity.com/2014/01/a-closer-look-at-the-target-malware-part-ii/; reference:url,krebsonsecurity.com/2014/01/a-first-look-at-the-target-intrusion-malware/; classtype:successful-recon-limited; sid:29456; rev:3; )
alert ( gid:119; sid:279; rev:1; msg:"(http_inspect) invalid status line"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO HTTP Request to a *.top domain
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO HTTP Request to a *.top domain"; flow:established,to_server; threshold:type limit, track by_src, count 1, seconds 30; http.host; content:".top"; fast_pattern; pcre:"/^(\x3a\d{1,5})?$/R"; reference:url,www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/shady-tld-research-gdn-and-our-2016-wrap; reference:url,www.spamhaus.org/statistics/tlds/; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2023882; rev:5; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2017_02_07, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2022_11_21;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET DNS Query to a *.top domain - Likely Hostile
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert dns $HOME_NET any -> any any (msg:"ET DNS Query to a *.top domain - Likely Hostile"; threshold:type limit, track by_src, count 1, seconds 30; dns.query; content:".top"; nocase; endswith; reference:url,www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/shady-tld-research-gdn-and-our-2016-wrap; reference:url,www.spamhaus.org/statistics/tlds/; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2023883; rev:4; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2017_02_07, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Major, updated_at 2020_09_15;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage"; flow:established,to_server; http.user_agent; content:"Mozilla/"; startswith; content:") WindowsPowerShell/"; distance:0; fast_pattern; classtype:not-suspicious; sid:2033355; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_07_16, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2021_07_16;)
alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP PING Windows"; itype:8; content:"abcdefghijklmnop",depth 16; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:382; rev:11; )
alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP PING"; icode:0; itype:8; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:384; rev:8; )
alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP Echo Reply"; icode:0; itype:0; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:408; rev:8; )

alert udp $HOME_NET any -> any 53 ( msg:"INDICATOR-COMPROMISE Suspicious .top dns query"; flow:to_server; byte_test:1,!&,0xF8,2; content:"|03|top|00|",fast_pattern,nocase; service:dns; reference:url,en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.top; classtype:misc-activity; gid:1; sid:43687; rev:3; )

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Binaries and Scripts in Public Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a file with a suspicious extension in the public folder, which could indicate potential malicious activity.

match_context.values: @{TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Documents\GtDBjndPJEao.ps1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Application File Write to Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Windows shells and scripting applications that write files to suspicious folders

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Documents\oKAuWheBXJSg.ps1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of a Windows system binary that is usually located in the system folder from an uncommon location.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Patrick Bareiss, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{CommandLine="%windir%\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -executionpolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -c "[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String(' [TRUNCATED]; Image=%windir%\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}
@{CommandLine=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; Image=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Read Contents From Stdin Via Cmd.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detect the use of "<" to read and potentially execute a file via cmd.exe

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /q /cC:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\jdzFY6cN.bat; Image=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=powershell -executionpolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -c "[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String(' [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Users\azure\AppData\Roaming\jdzFY6cN.ps1; ScriptBlockId=3afc17d6-88bb-4a9d-894b-f57d19e104b3; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

@{ScriptBlockText=powershell -executionpolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -c "[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String(' [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\jdzFY6cN.ps1; ScriptBlockId=981a3113-d2c3-46c4-a3c6-e908ab830ba8; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

@{ScriptBlockText=powershell -executionpolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -c "[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String(' [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\jdzFY6cN.ps1; ScriptBlockId=0cb005c7-6d0f-4d08-a47c-c1e4425ffae5; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious powershell invocations from interpreters or unusual programs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Documents\oKAuWheBXJSg.ps1; EventID=11}

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The code snippet is a VBScript that performs the following actions:

1. Sleeps for 21 seconds.
2. Creates a Shell object.  The code uses string concatenation to construct the "WScript.Shell" object.
3. Declares several variables with long, seemingly random names. These variables are potentially used for obfuscation.
4. Creates a FileSystemObject.  Again, string concatenation is used for this object creation, which could be used for obfuscation.
5. Retrieves the current hour and minute.
6. Performs conditional operations based on the current time.  If the minute is greater than 59, the hour and minute variables are incremented and decremented respectively, potentially creating a time-based trigger.
7. Creates two files.  If the current hour is less than 23, two files are created in the %APPDATA% directory. One file has a `.ps1` extension (PowerShell script), and the other has a `.bat` extension (batch script).  The contents of these files are written using a large string that appears obfuscated through the use of repetitive substrings.
8. Writes data to the created files. The `.ps1` file receives obfuscated code, likely a PowerShell command. The `.bat` file contains a command to execute the `.ps1` file via powershell, with the `-executionpolicy bypass` flag, which circumvents PowerShell execution policy restrictions.
9. Executes a command. A command is executed using the Shell object to run the batch file created previously. This execution is done through the `.Exec` method.
10. Creates a file. A file with a `.docx` extension is created in the user's Downloads folder. The filename appears to be derived from the script's name.
11. Checks for script existence. Finally, it checks if the script file itself exists and isn't located in a temporary directory; if so, it deletes the script file.


The obfuscation techniques used (long variable names, string concatenation, and repetitive substrings) hinder immediate understanding of the code's true functionality, which might pose a potential risk.  The script downloads no files from remote locations, but it does download and execute code from what seems to be locally stored, encoded data.
